titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Immediately after Breakfast I went down to Crane Wharf, and engaged a passage for my family and myself on board the Providence Packet, of Providence, Captain Russell— He told me Commodore Preble had also engaged a passage with him— He intends to sail, if the wind will permit to-morrow in the afternoon between 3 and 4 o’clock. I then called on Mr: M’Cormick— Attended the Court of Chancery, and the Circuit Court of the United States, both sitting in the City Hall— Heard Judge Patterson deliver a charge to the Grand-Jury— Met Judge Benson there, and Dr: Mitchill— The judge’s charge related principally to the neutral duties of the United States— On coming from the Court, I met Mr: Murray and his two Sisters, who came with me to visit our ladies.— I afterwards paid a visit to Mr: King— Mr: R. Bird called on me this morning, and desired me to meet his Assignees this Evening at 7. O’Clock, but afterwards requested me to meet them to-morrow morning at 9 to which I agreed. I took tea and pass’d the Evening at Dr: Mitchill’s; and saw his Lady— He shewed me a variety of new publications, and a letter from Mr: Livingston, our Minister in France, enclosing several pieces of seal-skins with the long fur, the short fur, and work’d into Cloth— He talks also of bringing home ploughs of improved form and other useful inventions.— When I came home I found Mr: & Mrs: King here on a visit to Mrs: Adams— Late this Evening Mr: Justus Smith desired to see me, and in a long conversation came finally to the point that he could make no settlement with me now; according to his repeated promises; but he offered me other security which I did not want; and he concluded with another promise to collect and pay me one half his note in the course of this year, and the remainder before the end of the next— This promise must for the present suffice me— I have experience enough to have taught me what is its worth.

2. I met this morning the Assignees of Robert Bird, at their Room, N. 4. William Street; but Mr: Hoffman was not there— After a couple of hours conversation with them, I went down to Crane Wharf, and found our Captain still determined upon departure this afternoon— Mr: Graves called upon me, and I had some conversation with him, respecting his demand against the Boston Marine Insurance Company— At 4 o’clock in the afternoon we embarked on board the Packet for Providence, and sailed at about 5. We pass’d Hellgate within an hour, and proceeded all Night with a light, but favourable breeze— We have about a dozen fellow-passengers, among whom are Commodore Preble, Mr: Leonard, and Mr: Hunnewell, Officers in the Navy, and Mr: Wadsworth a son of the Member of Congress from the district of Maine.

3. Our wind continued fair; but so very light that our progress was very slow. When we came to that part of the Passage called the Race, we found a very heavy and uncomfortable swell of the Sea, which continued untill we had pass’d the Light House, and were within two or three miles of Newport— In the afternoon and evening, we had so thick a fog, that we overshot Point Judith by several miles, before the Light-House was discovered— We anchored opposite Newport, at about 1. in the Morning— I occupy the few moments I can spare from attendance on the children, by perusing the Memoirs of Sir William Jones.

4. From the thickness of the fog, and the want of wind this morning, it was 10. O’Clock before we left our Anchorage opposite to Newport— Several of our fellow passengers, had previously landed there— Commodore Preble, and one or two others went on shore to breakfast; but returned before we sailed— Light winds, and calm prevailed untill 4 in the afternoon, when the wind came round to the North West, which was directly a-head to us; we then were obliged to beat up, untill we grounded, about a mile from Providence; we all went on shore in the boat, and took lodgings at Ammidon’s.— There we arrived between 8. & 9. in the Evening.

5. Commodore Preble took a Carriage, and left Providence about 6 this morning, for Boston. I engaged a Carriage also, to go directly to Quincy, without going to Boston— Mr: Wadsworth took a seat with us; to go into
Boston after setting us down. We left Providence about 10 O’Clock—dined at Dedham, and arrived at my father’s house, about 6 in the Evening— The distance from Providence is shortened several miles; and the roads are very much improved by the new turnpike, which is now completed to Patucket falls— Mr: Wadsworth proceeded in the Carriage we left, to Boston— My father and Mother were absent from home when we arrived; but soon after returned. My brother is at Haverhill.

6. A cold, stormy day, with rain and snow which confined me to the house all day— My brother returned from Haverhill, and dined with the club at Mr: Black’s— Mr: Shaw came out from Boston this Evening— I spent the day principally in reading.

7. Heard Mr: Richmond of Stoughton— Read in Butler’s Analogy, which I left unfinished on my departure from this place last October— Mr: Shaw returned this Evening to Boston— I find it necessary to deliberate upon some method for the employment of my time during the ensuing Summer, and I am desirous to occupy it more advantageously than I did the last Summer— That period was spent very laboriously, and to very little profit of any kind.

8. I went up to my own house this forenoon, and examined what would be necessary to be done upon it, before we go into it— Desired Briesler to engage me a Carpenter to begin to-morrow— The ladies went to Mr Black’s to tea; and I pass’d about an hour of the Evening there— The two Messrs: Greenleaf’s & their families; Mr: & Mrs: Boyes, Mrs: Holbrook, and some others were there.

9. I was confined to the house the whole day by the rains but the Office was filled with a succession of company that entirely prevented me from attending steadily to any thing— I have been reflecting upon some subject to employ usefully my leisure time this Summer, without yet coming to a decision— Commodore Preble, and Coll: T. H. Perkins came out here this morning from Boston— Mr: Perkins invited my father and me, to a public dinner, which is to be given to the Commodore to-morrow.— I purchased 20. Apple-trees to set out on my farm.

10. Went to Boston with my father, and attended at the dinner given to Commodore Preble— There were about 130 gentlemen present— Mrs: Adams and Eliza Johnson went to Boston with us— I transacted some business before dinner: but not much, it being too late before we went in to town— We called before and after dinner, at Mr: Smith’s; where the ladies dined. About 6 in the Evening we left Concert Hall and immediately afterwards returned to Quincy— I brought out Giffords Juvenal and some other books with me— My business at Boston was with the Banks and an Insurance Office; where I received the last dividend— On coming home we found Captain Beale and Miss Edes, at my father’s— They soon went away— I read Gifford’s translation of Juvenal’s first Satire.

11. I went up to my house this morning, but found the Carpenter had not been there, and Mr: Briesler was gone to Boston— Call’d at Mr: Cranch’s— I went there also this afternoon with the ladies to tea. Mr: Cranch has been unwell ever since I went from this place the last Autumn, and so continues. I read Gifford’s Account of his own life; and part of his prefaces.

12. Went up to my house, and found Mr: Page the Carpenter, at work there— Mrs: Adams and Eliza were also there— Mr: Quincy and Dr: Kirkland were here, but I was absent and did not see them— Read Gifford’s translation of Juvenal’s third and fourth Satires— Compared the third with Johnson’s London, and with the 1st: and 6th: Satires of Boileau— Of all these Poems, the London, is the most beautiful.— George 4 years old. 3. f. 2. i.

13. My father went to Boston, to attend a meeting of the agricultural Society, respecting the establishment of a botanical Garden, and a professorship of Natural History at Cambridge. I attended a meeting of the Directors of Neponsit Bridge, at the Bridge— Went with Mr: T. Greenleaf— All the Directors were present— The business is to be done in future, by monthly Committees of three members— I was chosen with Mr: Greenleaf and Mr: Black for this Month— My brother dined with the club at Mr: Millar’s— Towards evening, I walk’d with my wife and Eliza Johnson. About dusk my father return’d from town, well pleased with his excursion. I read the 5th: Satire of Juvenal in Gifford; and made some progress in revising my own translation of the 7th:

14. Heard Mr: Whitney— Communion day— Having met an accident and hurt my foot, I have been unable to walk much— Finished revising my translation of Juvenal’s 7th: Satire— Read also Gifford’s translation of the 6th: that bitter invective against the sex, which stagger’d the fortitude of Dryden— I was so much occupied with this as to do nothing else.

15. I was this day quite unwell; but walk’d up to my house, where I found the mason at work— Sent into Boston for various Articles of necessary use for my family— I continue to read Gifford’s Juvenal;—went through the 7th: and 8th:— Dr: Tufts was here this forenoon.

16. I went with Mr: Black to Mr: Josh: Bass’s, and thence to the road near the Bridge, which is to be repaired; we took the admeasurements with a water-level—postponed for a day or two the final agreement with Mr: Bass— Mr: Jos: Hall, and Mr: Gardner were out here this afternoon to tea; as were Mr: and Mrs: Cranch— I could only get time to read the 9th: Satire of Gifford’s translation— The subject and its treatment are very disgusting— George is quite unwell.

17. I attended at the sale at public Auction of the late Mr: Shaw’s house and farm— The buildings and about 70 Acres of land sold for $8650— Several other pieces of land sold at the same time— 7. Acres of Salt-marsh at $127 per Acre— 4. Acres of young wood for $56 per Acre— And 2 Acres of Cedar swamp for $15.— Some articles of furniture were likewise sold.— In the afternoon, Mr: Black and Mr T. Greenleaf called on me, and we went to view the spot where the road is to be widened, by a removal of the wall on my father’s Land— There was a numerous company of Ladies at tea here this Evening— After which I met at Mr: Black’s, Mr: Greenleaf & Mr: Bass, with whom we agreed for repairing a spot of the Neponsit Bridge Road— I was late in the Evening there— George still unwell— I read Gifford’s 10th: and 11th Satires of Juvenal.— The subject of the 11th: is pleasing—that of the 10th: admirable.

18. We this day began to move our furniture into the old house in which I was born— I went there, in the forenoon with Mrs: Adams, and also down to Mitchell’s, where most of our furniture has been kept since our removal from Boston— In the afternoon I went with Mr: T. Greenleaf to Neponsit Bridge, and view’d the spot which is to be repaired— Took tea, and pass’d the Evening, at Captain Beale’s— Weather very warm— Peach and Plum-trees in bloom.— Read the 12th: and 13th: Satires of Gifford’s Juvenal— Compared the 13th: with my own translation published in the first number of the Port-Folio.

19. My father, mother and brother, went into Boston this morning. I went with Mrs: Adams to Mitchell’s, and thence to our own house; where we put in order, part of the furniture— Mrs: Adams went there again after dinner— I read Gifford’s 14th: and part of the 15th: Satire of Juvenal—the 14th: is incomplete, in the volume I have— One sheet of letter-press being missing, and a duplicate of the next sheet substituted in its stead. I compared my translation of the 14th: Satire, with Gifford’s; which is much better— Mine is indeed very indifferent, and requires at least as much revision as I have given the 7th: and 13th: to stand on a level with them.

20. The weather being foul, I did not go up to my house this morning. Dined at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s, with the Saturday’s club. Mr: Lazell came in after dinner— I desired him, to dispose of the shares for which I had subscribed in the New-Bedford Turnpike— I finished reading Gifford’s translation of Juvenal.

21. Heard Mr: Harris of Dorchester; who with his friend, a Major Lincoln of Marietta dined with us at my father’s— We had an Easterly storm which confined us the remainder of the day to the house.— I this day finished reading Butler’s Analogy; and began to compare Gifford’s translation of Juvenal with the original. I find myself attracted irresistibly towards studies of this Nature, which will probably never be of much use to me in the world.

22. I continued confined to the house, the greatest part of this day by foul weather— Mrs: Cranch was here at tea— I am still reading Juvenal, and comparing him with his translator Gifford— I also read part of Cicero’s Oration for Quinctius, and consulted the Journals of Congress— Wrote a little, in the Evening.

23. Finished the comparison of Juvenal’s first Satire with Gifford’s translation— Sent my furniture to my house. I went up there myself this afternoon— Pruned a number of trees— Called at Mr: Cranch’s, this Evening— I still continue to waste my time very unprofitably.— Trees from stones, first appeared.

24. Went into Boston this morning with Mrs: Adams, after going first up to our own house— Call’d on Mr: Shaw; at Mr: Smith’s, and at Dr: Welsh’s— Also to see Mr: Dexter, but he was not in town— And twice at Mr: Russell’s, but found him also absent— So that the principal business upon which I went remains unfinished— Dined with Mr: Quincy— Mrs: Adams dined at Mrs: Whitcomb’s— I saw Mr: Gardner, and partly arranged my business with him; but did not accomplish it.— We returned home before Night, with rainy weather— I received a long expected letter from Mr: Williams in London.

25. My wife came up to our own house this morning and here remained— After dinner I came, with Eliza and the two children— Returned to my father’s with the Chaise, and early in the Evening came home; to the house in which I was born; but in which I have not before pass’d a Night, for upwards of twenty-five years. My brother came and pass’d a half an hour with us— I had a number of Peach, pear and cherry trees set out this afternoon; in the spot I have allotted for a nursery.— On going back to my father’s house, I found Mr: and Mrs: Smith of Boston there, and Mrs: Cranch.— On coming into my own house, I am entering upon a new mode of life, as it regards my family and myself— It is attended with many circumstances upon which I am not desirous to dwell; but as it was dictated by necessity, so I hope it will eventually prove highly advantageous to us all— That it will enure us to some of its inconveniences, and enable us to remove others— That it will reduce our desires to a level with our circumstances, and compensate to us in safety, whatever it may take from us in elegance or ease— I have taken this step upon full and long deliberation— More than two years since the occasion happened, which made it necessary— The determination was then taken, which is now carrying into effect— Here I purpose to reside during the Summer Seasons; in the intervals from my attendance upon Congress— At the expiration of my term of service, my intention is to remove again into Boston; if possible— In these measures, my intention is to do all in my power, for the preservation of my family— The issue must be beyond my controul— May it be auspicious!

26. Heavy rain all the morning— About noon the sky cleared away; but became showery again towards Evening. My brother; my mother and Mrs: Cranch called to see us— I set out to go to my father’s, but was overtaken by a shower, which stop’d me at Mr: Cranch’s— Here I found a son and daughter of Mr: Gannett of Cambridge, on a visit. Before the rain ceased it was so late that I concluded to return home— I employed the day chiefly in reading Juvenal’s second Satire, and comparing it with Gifford’s translation— In the Evening, read two Acts of Much Ado about Nothing; to the Ladies.

27. Mr: Apthorp called upon me this morning, on business of Law— My father also was here— In the afternoon I went to his house— Home early— Read to the Ladies Acts 3 and 4. of Much Ado about Nothing— I finished the comparison of Juvenal’s second Satire with the translation.— George dined at my father’s but soon insisted upon coming home— He is very unwell, with the whooping cough; and is particularly ill in the Night.

28. Heard Mr: Bates of Dedham this morning— In the afternoon I went with my wife and Eliza to Church, and heard Mr: Blackburn— My brother dined with us— I went with Eliza, this afternoon to my father’s— We returned home early in the Evening. Mr: Shaw and Mr: Walter were out, from Boston.— George continues unwell.— I still read Juvenal with the translation; and this day began the 3d: Satire.

29. Walk’d down with my wife, and Eliza Johnson to my father’s house— Then to Mr: T. Greenleaf’s— And returned early in the Evening, across the fields— Finished reading to the Ladies, Much Ado about Nothing.— I was employed part of the day about my farm.

30. I went to Dedham this morning with my brother— The Courts of Common Pleas and Sessions met there— Saw Messrs: Townsend—B. Whitman—T. Williams and others— I dined with them at Dedham, and returned alone early in the afternoon— Received letters from Mr: Hellen, and Mr: W. Cranch— The latter declining to undertake the Administration of Mr: Johnson’s Estate— I stop’d at Mr: Cranch’s, on my return.

Day— During the first days of this month I was travelling from New-York to Quincy— Then pass’d about three weeks at my father’s house, and have now been only five or six days settled in my own— I have therefore not as yet got into any regular course of life and occupations— Similar causes occasioned the omission of any account at the close of the last Month, under this Article.
